Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC University of Connecticut: Center for Networked Embedded, Smart and Trusted Things NESTT

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Connecticut will work together with the Arizona State University, University of Southern California, University of Arizona, and Southern Illinois University to form a new NSF Industry University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) for Networked Embedded, Smart and Trusted Things (NESTT). The vision of NESTT is to contribute to the development of an equitable, safe and secure connected world. NESTT will achieve this vision by focusing on creating holistic IoT solutions, integrating technology disciplines with expertise in law, business, and humanities.

The objective of the UConn's site planning project is to hold workshops with industry partners and NESTT partner universities. The goal of these workshops is to outline a research agenda and identify industry support for an IUCRC focused on providing IoT solutions specific to cyber-physical systems, IOT requirements and architecture, cybersecurity, industrial IOT for smart manufacturing, smart buildings, grid modernization, and transportation. These application areas will be supported by UConn's expertise in systems engineering, distributed edge and cloud computing, formal methods, machine learning, data analytics, cyber-physical security, prognostics and diagnostics.

The multidisciplinary research at NESTT aims to integrate societal and technological aspects of IoT as a systems engineering and design problem. New scientific discoveries in NESTT and their integration with industrial practice could enable economic growth, and provide societal and environmental benefits. Access and opportunities to students who are underrepresented in STEM disciplines and relevant technology areas will be a priority. UConn's NESTT will engage with the UConn Multicultural Scholars Program, the McNair Scholars Undergraduate Research Program, liaisons at HBCUs, the National GEM Consortium, the Northeast Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate, and Summer Research Programs for minority students.

The agenda, list of participants and outcomes of the UConn's NESTT IUCRC planning workshops will be posted online at UConn under the auspices of the UTC Institute for Advanced Systems Engineering (http://utc-iase.uconn.edu ) and promoted through its social media venues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Connecticut worked together with the Arizona State University, University of Southern California, University of Arizona, and Southern Illinois University to form a new NSF Industry University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) for Networked Embedded, Smart and Secure Things (NESST). The vision of NESST is to contribute to the development of an equitable, safe and secure connected world. NESST will achieve this vision by focusing on creating holistic IoT solutions, integrating technology disciplines with expertise in law, business, and humanities.
The objective of the UConn's site planning grant was to hold workshops with industry partners and NESST partner universities. The goal of these workshops was to outline a research agenda and identify industry support to an IUCRC focused on providing IoT solutions specific to cyber-physical systems, IOT requirements and architecture, cybersecurity, industrial IOT for smart manufacturing, smart buildings, grid modernization, and transportation. These application areas will be supported by UConn?s expertise in systems engineering, distributed edge and cloud computing, formal methods, machine learning, data analytics, cyber-physical security, prognostics and diagnostics.

A workshop was organized May 16 - 17, 2019 in Phoenix, AZ. Leading technology companies joined researchers from the five particiapting universities for two days to share engineering, legal and business challenges they face as they integrate loT technologies into their businesses. A substantial outreach activity was planned and executed that involved participation of over 50 faculty members and industry representatives along with graduate students and NSF program managers. The worshop helped reshape the focus of NESST into three Industry domains: (a) Mobile, Edge and Cloud Computing; (b) Industrial, Medical, Retail IoT;  and (c) Transportation and Infrastructure. Faculty presented brief preliminary research projects to the industry participants in these three topics and had the opportunity to ellaborate on these projects in follow-up poster sessions. Industry participants provided feedback on these topics and overall on the mission and focus of NESST. UConn participated in this meeting with 5 faculty and 4 industry partners. It also communicated the mission and value of NESST to over 30 new industry partners. It has secured the interest for membership by 5 industry partners. The UConn team along with the 4 university partners is now working on the development of the proposal for the IUCRC execution.  

The projects presented in the NESST kick-off meeting can be found online at: https://nesst.asu.edu/projects/. In brief the titles of the projects presented are listed below: 

Mobile, edge and cloud computing
- Empowering Edge Computing with FPGAs 
- Software Architectures for Secure and Reliable Connected Mobile Systems 
- Machine Learning on the Edge 
- Reasoning Methods for Connected and Autonomous CyberPhysical Systems 
- Hardware Accelerators in IoT Devices for Deep Learning 
- Intelligent Software-Defined Wireless Networking for IoT using Deep Reinforcement Learning 
- Secure Reliable and Efficient Edge Processing for IoT 

Industrial, medical and retail IoT
- Uncertainty Quantification and Global Sensitivity Analysis in Machine Learning 
- Lifting Mobile Medical Technology to Communities 
- Smart Contracts for Conducting Business in an Analytics of Things Era 
- Cancer Care Augmented Reality for Bridging Patient Experiences 
- Functional Safety Standards of Embedded ICs in IoT ? Evaluating Resiliency to Radiation Effects 
- Safe and Reliable AI for the Workplace 
- Wearables for Precision Medicine 

Transportation and infrastucture
- Personalized Deep Learning Systems for Autonomous Vehicles with Real Time Diagnostics 
- Reliability and Security Considerations on Smart Grids 
- Decentralized IoT Marketplaces for Smart Cities 
- Towards a Software-Defined High-Speed Industrial IoT Infrastructure for Advanced Manufacturing 
- Linked Data Infrastructure for Smart Manufacturing 
- IoT-Enabled Optimization for Reliable and Efficient Building Systems 
- IoT-Enabled Urban Met Networks and PV Energy 

The detailed project descriptions can be found on https://nesst.asu.edu/projects/.
